The resolution was ably sustained by Messrs. Wilcox and Foote, and the highest eulogiums passed upon the heroes of the Southwest.

The reports from the Military Committee, through their chairman, Mr. Miles, were of a practical character, and evidenced the determination of the House to render every aid in promoting the efficiency of the army.
The bills for the appointment of artillery officers, for the increase of the engineer corps, and for the organization of a signal corps, are all measures of utility, and should perhaps ere this have engaged the consideration of Congress.

We believe that hitherto the engineer corps of our army has been totally insufficient for the labors required of it, and engineer officers have been greatly needed in several of the departments.
We are credibly informed that Gen. Jackson has been applying since November for a competent engineer, and to this day his application has not been filled for want of that class of officers.

div3.head: Improved gun.
div3.p:
We are inclined to believe that the new breech-loading rifle invented by Mr. C. W. Alexander, is the very best arm of that kind yet invented.
It would be well for the army if it were possible now to furnish it with a large supply of this pattern of gun. Mr. Alexander, who is now in this city, desires to secure the co-operation of manufacturers in the manufacture of his rifle.
A lucrative business might be done in this enterprise, and we trust, as well for the sake of our cause as for the benefit of a gentleman who merits success, that some one who has manufacturing skill and means will undertake it at once.
Mr. A.'s rifle has received the unqualified approval of the proper officers in the Ordnance Department of the Government.

div3.head: Give Aid to the Volunteers.
div3.p:
A fine and very full company has just been raised by Capt. Marmaduke Johnson.
It is composed of excellent material, and will give a good account of itself when the time for action comes.
It is not yet fully equipped, and the assistance of the citizens is solicited to facilitate its early equipment.
We hope it will be most liberally aided.
The generous assistance of his townsmen will be most cheering and encouraging to the gallant soldier who is about to devote his time, and possibly his life, to the defense of his country.
See advertisement.

div3.head: A brave and daring act.
div3.p:
--Private James Oden, of Captain Meade's company, 6th Virginia cavalry, on a recent occasion, alone, captured five men of the 12th and 13th Massachusetts regiments, who surrendered to him their loaded Enfield rifles, and were marched off as prisoners by this gallant son of Loudoun county!
The fact was officially announced to the brigade on the 1st inst., by Gen. J. E. B. Stuart, who says in his order:

q.p: "This daring enterprise shows how little numbers avail against genuine courage and bold determination; and the heroic example of Oden is commended to the emulation of his comrades, and receives the warmest praise."

div3.head: A Misstatement corrected.
div3.p: --A letter from a gentleman at Campball Court-House, Va., calls our attention to a recent announcement that "seventy traitors from Loudoun" had just arrived in Richmond, He says:--

q.p:
"Having lived there, and left after our army did, I know that the statement is not correct.
They came from another county.
The people of Loudoun, and of Leesburg particularly, are proving themselves not only staunch, but extreme Southern men."

div3.p: We are indebted to Mr. M. W. Ray, bearer of dispatches, for late New Orleans and Mobile papers.
Henry C. Seymour, of the firm of Stratton & Seymour, of Nashville, Tennessee, died in Marion, Ga., on Thursday last.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia — a proclamation.
div3.p: --Whereas, a vacancy has occurred in the House of Delegates of Virginia by the resigna of Richardieby, the member elected from the District composed of the counties of Amelia and Nortoway; Therefore, I John Letcher, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, by virtue of authority vested in the Executive by law, do hereby require the h riffs of the said counties of melia and Nottoway to hold an election, at the several places of voting prescribed by law in said counties, of the rth day of the present month, (April,) for a Delegate to fill the vacancy aforesaid.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 7th day of April, 1852, and in the year of the Commonwealth the eighty-sixth.
div3.closer:
By the Governer;
John Leicher.
George W. Bufford,
Secretary of the Commonwealth.
Petersburg papers please copy. ap 10 td

div3.p:
I have been authorized by the Secretary Ofwar.
a raise a Regiment of Navy Artillery for three years of the war.
filling up and wants a few mplet on, I should who have also with these who desire to raise companies

"Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, of the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable at as they are into service and upon it by a medical officer, to the time and place of enlistment, until inspected "
men can re-enlist or by companies for two years or the war and recieve $50 bounty; and wil also be transferred during the twenty dys previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteerd will be received or by sompa from an, portion of the confederacy.

Office--Tenth street, three door from Main.
By Post. Office, Box 277

General Orders, no. 6,

list.item:

Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or our of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.

div3.head:
Headquarters Ordnance Department, Richmond.
Va., March 25th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting state arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.
Whig and Enquirer copy. mh 29--tf

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 87, page 4.

div3.head:
Interesting from Europe.
Atlantic telegraph Company--the English Press on American affairs.
div3.p: We continue our selections from the European news by the latest arrivals:

div4.head: Great Britain.
div4.p: At the annual meeting of the Atlantic Telegraphic Company, Hon. James Stewart Wortley, who occupied the chair, stated that Seward had addressed a dispatch to the American Ambassador at London, requesting him to bring the subject of telegraphic communication under the notice of the English Government, and offering to join in the enterprise.
Lord Palmerston promised to receive the deputation on the 21st inst., which would be composed of members of Parliament and others interested in telegraphy.

The following were elected directors in the place of those retiring by rotation: London — George Peabody, Francis Lebreton, and John M. Brett.
New York — Cyrus W. Field and Wm. E. Dod, Halifax — Thomas C. Kinnear.

The deputation above-mentioned waited on Lord Palmerston on Friday.
It was large and influential, comprising members of Parliament, bankers, merchants, and others.--They strongly urged upon Government the importance of connecting the two countries by a telegraphic cable from Ireland to New Fordland.
Lord Palmerston promised to bring the subject before his colleague, and the interview is said to have been very satisfactory to all parties.
The steamer Stella, from New York, with goods for the Great Exhibition, has arrived at Plymouth.

Government has invited tenders for the construction of an iron steamer on Captain Cole's plan.
It is to be fitted with six cupo each armed with two Armstrong 100 pounders.

div4.head: Prussia.
div4.p: The King has issued a proclamation, in which he firmly declares his adherence to the principles which he announced in November, 1862.

It is his earnest desire to insure the complete effectiveness of the Constitution, and maintain the right of the Crown, as a weakening of the Crown would be greatly injurious to the fatherland.
Foreign policy, especially towards Germany, is to be maintained without change.
He charged the Ministry of State to carry out his principles, and looks with confidence to the support of

div4.head: Greece.
div4.p: A deputation from Nauplia had arrived at Athens, imploring the King's clemency.
A dispatch from Syria says that the royal troops had restored order throughout the island.

div4.head: Former Commercial news.
div4.p: Liverpool Produce Market.--The Brokers Circular reports: Sugar Inactive Coffee firm.--Rice quiet and steady Raisin has an upward tendency; common, 12s, 6d.12s. 9d. Spirits Turpentine advancing, and 68s a70s.

London Money Market.--Funds on the 21st were firmer, under the favorable Bank statement and improvement at Paris.
Consol closed firm and advancing.
Money very easy.
The bullion in the Bank is higher, with one exception, than at any time since 1859.

London Markets--Breadstuffs dull.
Iron dull.
Sugar a downward tendency.--Coffee firmer and advancing.
Tea quiet, with a trifling advance; common Congou, 18 1½c. Rice very dull.
Spirit's Turpentine, irregular, and quoted at 68a70

Consol closed on Friday evening at 93¾ a 94.
The bullion in the Bank of England has increased £511,000.

American Securities--There has been a fair business, but quotations, in many cases, are nominal.
United States 6's, 82a84; United States 5's, 76a77; Massachusetts 5's, 94a96; Maryland 5's,80; Illinois Central shares, 43 dis; New York Central, 72a74; Erie, 33¼.

div4.head:
English Opinion.
[from the London Standard, March 14]
div4.p:
It would seem that the Confederate States are much more closely blockaded by land than by sea. They can import arms; they could if they would export cotton and tobacco.
But that which used to come to us overland, through the United States post-office, has not yet found a safe channel for itself — Letters and newspapers seem but rarely to run the blockade, and we are left with comparatively little information as to the condition of Southern affairs.
What we receive through the North is so untruthful and so willfully perverted as to be worse than none.
Strict precautions have been taken to prevent unpleasant truths from reaching the cars of the Northern people or of foreign readers of Northern newspapers.--Nothing can be published by these organs without the permission of Mr. Seward, who has caused military possession to be taken of the various lines of telegraph, and has made use of very effective means of terrorism, exclusion from the mails, prosecutions before servile tribunals, and the severities of club law, in order to check the publication of any obnoxious reports which the editors may receive through such channels as cannot be closed in a similar manner.
Consequently the Northern press has a monopoly of falsehood, and the independent journals are wholly stopped from contradiction.
We may not, therefore, place the least reliance on any statement relative to the situation of the Confederate States, the policy of their Government or the feelings of their people, which rest on the authority of the Northern journals or the partizans of the Federal Government in this country.
The utmost pains are taken, first, to preclude them from knowing the truth; and, secondly, to deter them from speaking it. On the other hand, we receive very little intelligence direct from the South, but what we do receive seems to be thoroughly trustworthy.
The exigencies of the struggle had a sobering effect upon the journals and statement of the Confederacy, and they are too hard at work and too much in earnest for falsehood and braggadocio.

And, moreover, they do not write or speak for an audience like that to which Mr. Seward and the New York Herald or Tribune address themselves.
Their appeal is to man of property and education, commanding the confidence and guarding the destinies of their fellow-citizens; not to the alien rabble of New York or the fanatical abolitionists of Boston.
There has always been a remarkable difference between the political systems of the two sections of the late Union; the institutions of both have been absolutely democratic, but the Northern democracy has been governed by its tail, the Southern by its head.
The Senators of the North generally, its representatives almost invariably, have been demagogues, intriguers, or nobodies; those of the South have been more frequently statement and gentleman.
The same difference still exists, and while the bewildered men who administer the Government of Washington are obliged to conciliate and manage as best they can, by falsehood, flattery, intimidation, or cajolery, a Congress of vestrymen, Mr. Davis is surrounded by the elite of the intelligence and statesmanship of the South, to whom he can and must speak the truth.
Without supposing him to be an honester man than Mr. Lincoln, or an abler man than Mr. Stanton, it is quite clear that a far higher value attaches to his assertions and to his language than theirs.
What they may say signifies little; it is spoken to Bunkum.
We know that it affords no real proof either of what they have done or what they mean to do. Mr. Davis's tone, as well as his position, offer a tolerable guarantee for the sincerity and earnestness of his meaning.
The Standard then enlogizes the resolute tone of Jeff. Davis's message, and concludes thus:

q.p:
"The Northerners have shown themselves as incapable of bearing success as of enduring adversity.
Their triumph at Fort Donelson has made them mad with vain-glory.
We believe, with some of the best informed and most thoughtful of those whose personal interests are deeply involved, that the hope of peace is, for the present, as remote and doubtful as ever."

div3.head:
[for the Richmond Dispatch.]
religious Treats for the Soldiers — distributors Wanted.
div3.p:
We now have at our depository, in this city, upwards of two millions of pages of religious tracts, a large assortment of the hymn books of the various religious denominations; also, several thousand dollars' worth of religious books.
Being anxious to furnish the soldiers in every division of the army with suitable reading matter, I take this method of informing all who can aid in this matter that they will be supplied gratuitously with our publications.
We have at this time over one hundred tract distributors, and desire to secure the services of as many more.
We have depositories in Norfolk, Fredericksburg, Charlottesville, Staunton, Lynchburg, and Marion, as also at prominent points in other States Members of Christian Associations, Soldiers' Aid Societies, and all others who feel interested in the moral culture of the soldiers, are invited to avail themselves of this opportunity to secure for general distribution tracts written by persons of the different religious denominations, and acceptable to all. A. E. Dickinson.

div3.head: N. C. Free Market
div3.p: --The cash receipts of the New Orleans Free Market for the month of March were $15,622.68; receipts of produce, $4,118.05; total $19,146.78. The total expenses during the same period were $12,861.17. The number of families supplied was 15,149.

div3.head: Southern Methodise Publishing House.
div3.p: --This establishment, driven from Nashville by the enemy, will commence operations in Mobile shortly.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va, April 9th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 13.

Paragraphs 1 and 2, General Orders No. 12 Headquarters Department of Henrico, issued March 31st, 1862, are not confined in their operation to venders of produce in the markets, but apply to Grocers, Commission Merchants, and every character of dealer in provisions within the city and the surrounding ten miles of country under martial law. All sales of provisions must conform to the Tariff of Prices prescribed by paragraph II.
of General Orders, No. 12; and where not adhered to, both buyer and seller will suffer such punishment as may be imposed by a court martial, and the produce thus sold will be forfeited to the informer, who, if interested in the sale, is exempted from punishment.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig-Gen. John H Winder.
L. R. Page,
Ass't Adj't General. ap 10--2w

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or Regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time, and I now purpose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry.

Persons desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call at the office of the Battalion, Main street, Richmond, Va., opposite the office of the Southern Express Company.

div3.head:
Adj't & Irsp.
General's Office,
Richmond, April 8th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 80.

II.

div3.head:
Headquarters,
Pates' Battalion.
div3.p: We, the undersigned, are authorized by Capt Henry C. Pate, to recruit A Company of Cavalry, consisting of 60 men, to be mustered into the service of the C. S. A for 3 years or during the war. Members joining this company are entitled to the bounty of $50 and $12 per month pay.

Horses, equipments, and subsistence, furnished each recruit.
Those who furnish their own horses, will be entitled to $25 per month.
Office on Main and near the corner of 9th street, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
McNARY Hosson,
C. F. Harwood.
Norfolk Day Book, Petersburg Express and Richmond Examiner will please copy and send bill to the subscribers. ap 7--10t*

div3.head: Infantry Company.
div3.p: The undersigned being authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Light Infantry for the war, and having united with Mr. Charles H. Exall, and Mr. Wm. J. Eggleston, and G. W. Jones in the enterprise, has opened a Recruiting Office on the West side of 10th street, between Main and Bank. Men enlisting in this company will receive the usual bounty, &c.
This company will form a part of the battalion of infantry being raised by R. G. Scott, Jr., Esq., who may be found at the same office.

div3.head: Attention, Patriots.
div3.p:
A few more Recruits wanted for Courtney's Artillery, now stationed at Rappahannock river.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid.
Apply at the Franklin Rouse, on 6th between Broad and Marshall streets, to
div3.closer:
Lieut. R. H. Vaughn,
Or C. M. Christian. ap 7--10t*

div3.head:
Adj't and Insp'r Gen's Office,
Richmond, April 8, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 80.
[Extract]

XVIII.
On the discharge of troops leaving the service the commanders of regiments and battalions will take away all arms of every description, whether public or private — private arms to be paid for by the Ordnance officer, or receipts even which will entitle holders to payment.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
Jno. Withers. A. A. G. ap 9--1w

div3.head:
War Department.
Adj't and Insp. General's Office,
Richmond, April 8th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 21.

list.item:
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
proclamation:
"By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:
"I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the Department of East Tennessee under the command of Major-General E. K. Smith; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the states of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the mention of the writ of habeas corpus in the Department aforesaid.
"In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal this 8th day of April, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
[Signed] Jefferson Davis."

II. Major General E. K. Smith, commanding Department of East Tennessee, is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation.--He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders: All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court-martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper.
Adj't and Inspector General. ap 8--6t

div3.head:
Headq'rs Recruiting station
4th Alabama Reg't Volunteers,
109 Main street.
div3.p: the following named men have deserted from this station and the Government reward will be paid for their apprehension:
2d Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery.
$50 bounty, and Uniforms furnishes.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, upstairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Crutchfield Light Artillery.
March 13th, 1862.
div3.p: Attention, Volunteers!
Battery secured.

The undersigned, having secured a splendid Battery of field-pieces, have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be mustered in the Provisional Army of Virginia for the war, and have received authority from the Governor to recruit volunteers from the Militia.
to fill the ranks of the Crutchfield Light Artillery.
The company will be mustered in as soon as a sufficient number of volunteers have been received.
A fine opportunity now presents itself to those who do not wish to go as militiamen, to enroll themselves as volunteers.
No substitutes received.
Apply at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company, under the St Charles Hotel.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.

div3.head: $50 bounty--Crescent Zouaves Satiation,
div3.p:
Wanted--Recruit to fill up the battalion of Crescent Zouaves, under the command of Major W. Hyllested.
A bounty of fifty dollars will, be paid each recruit upon enlistment.
A neat uniform of gray cloth, Zouave style, will be furnished.

This corps will be one of the best organized and equipped in the service, and its commander having had many years' military experience, both in this and foreign countries, will make it a battalion worthy of the admiration of his commanding General, and one that young men will be proud to serve in. Those wishing to enlist will apply to
div3.closer:
Capt. Wm. T. Fry,
Recruiting Officer,
No. 5 Exchange Block,
Under Exchange Hotel. ap 1--2w*

div3.head:
Head'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 54.

VI.
Recruits, with or without officers is charge, convalescents and other soldiers now or hereafter detained in this city, for any cause whatever, will immediately proceed to Camp Winder, near the Reservoir and report to Colonel John C. Porter, commanding at that post.
div3.closer:
By order of Brigadier General John H.
Winder. L. R. Page,
Assistant Adjutant General. mh 8t--d4w

div3.head: Attention, Teamsters.
div3.p:
--I wish to ten good Drivers for my Battery.
To experienced men, I will give $50 each in addition to the Government bounty of $50.
Volunteers now in service but whose term in enlistment will expire during this month, will be received upon application to the undersigned by letter, at Camp Lee, near Richmond.

div3.head: Wise Zouaves.
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of Infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves in compliment of the memory of the 1st Captain Wise.
This company will be instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardigon in the Zouave drill of the French Infantry, and taught by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar is all its detail, and having aided Captain Car in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service.

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Lind.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 14 Pearl street, or by mail to

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Capt. Wm. W. Parker's Company of Light Artillery having been transferred into service, and secured a battery of six guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits, if they of the right sort.
Apply at his office, in the Law Building at once.
